node.title: Pfizer files for emergency authorization of its COVID-19 pill
node.description: The drugmaker is asking regulators to authorize its experimental coronavirus pill for people with mild to moderate infections.
node.content: ["Pfizer is asking federal regulators to authorize its experimental\u00a0COVID-19 pill, which the drugmaker says can protect people from the most severe symptoms of the disease.\u00a0", "Pfizer on Tuesday said it is seeking Emergency Use Authorization for the antiviral pill, called Paxlovid, from the Food and Drug Administration. Earlier this month, the company said Paxlovid cut the risk of hospitalization and death by nearly 90% in people with mild to moderate coronavirus infections.\u00a0", "The pharmaceutical giant, which also produces a coronavirus vaccine, earlier on Tuesday announced that it has signed a deal with a U.N.-backed group to allow other manufacturers to make the COVID-19 pill, a move that could make the treatment available to more than half of the world's population.\u00a0", "\"The overwhelming efficacy achieved in our recent clinical study of Paxlovid, and its potential to help save lives and keep people out of the hospital if authorized, underscores the critical role that oral antiviral therapies could play in the battle against COVID-19,\" Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla said in a statement.\u00a0", "Other drugmakers are also developing a pill to treat COVID-19. An FDA panel is scheduled to meet on November 30 to weigh a potential emergency use authorization for molnupiravir, an antiviral drug developed by\u00a0Merck\u00a0and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics that recently\u00a0won authorization in the United Kingdom.", "Merck says its drug, called molnupiravir, halved the risk that adult COVID-19 patients with underlying health conditions ended up in the hospital or died from the disease.\u00a0", "Both Merck's and Pfizer's antiviral drugs are swallowed in capsules for five days starting soon after higher-risk patients test positive for the virus. Both pills are designed to reduce the risk of severe disease in the early days after infection, but they work in different ways.", "Pfizer says its pill halts the virus from spreading in a person's body by deploying a new compound that can bind to an enzyme of the virus, blocking it from replicating inside infected cells. Merck's drug, based on a drug first developed at\u00a0Emory University\u00a0to combat the flu, tries to harness the body's cells to block the virus from replicating.\u00a0", "Paxlovid works similarly to\u00a0remdesivir, an antiviral drug approved by the FDA last year to treat COVID-19. But the pills would be easier to administer because remdesivir must be given as an I.V. in a hospital or clinic.", "Alexander Tin contributed reporting.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
